awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Heterogeneous GPU Cluster to Facilitate Deep Learning Research at UMBC
awd_abstract_narration:
This project acquires an instrument to pursue large-scale, data-intensive, end-to-end research, aiming to service several fields that include natural language processing (NLP), robotics, computer vision (CV), computer graphics, cybersecurity, medical analysis, and other heavily statistical areas. Utilizing very large data sets and performing intensive computation using Graphics Processing Units (GPU), the work focuses on vastly expanding the GPU computation power, storage, and access to data. This effort aims to reflect the discipline-wide shift within engineering towards model and system-building that require GPU computation and a continued focus within some computer and information science and engineering (CISE) disciplines towards deep learning and big data in need of big storage arrays, high memory servers, and horizontal scaling capabilities. The instrument contributes in preparing students with the skill to use clusters and other tools for handling large problems with the help of the cluster.

Researchers will be able to tackle problems in various areas with the heterogeneous architecture of the cluster, since cluster-based computing can increase availability, reliability, and scalability. Moreover, performance on tasks that can be parallelized might be improved. Deep learning techniques will likely improve performance in predictive modeling. In turn, the cluster facilitates research across multiple discipline, it enables work in robotics, healthcare, medicine, as well as trust and fairness in machine learning. The proposal supports young faculty, women, and underrepresented minority groups such as UMBC (University of Maryland-Baltimore County), Meyerhoffer, and CWIT (Center of Women in Technology).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We have acquired a GPU cluster to advance deep learning research across UMBC campus. Moreover, we installed the necessary software to make it a shared resource across the whole UMBC campus. This includes installing “slurm”, a job management software used by many clusters including the national supercomputers, which manages a queue of jobs so that multiple users can use the resource efficiently at the same time. We put together quick-start documentation to make it easier for users to start using the cluster and the job scheduler, and worked with new researchers to ensure they understood how to operate within the cluster environment. We made the cluster available to any researcher at UMBC (faculty members and students). To increase the outreach, we advertised it along with sharing the simple-to-use instructions and ways to get support.

 

This cluster has been used by a broad research community across UMBC campus that goes well beyond the PIs or even the Computer Science and Electrical Engineering department. For instance, almost 30% of the usage (GPU-hours) is from researchers at the department of biology. This cluster has enabled UMBC researchers (including several junior faculty members) to conduct world class research involving deep learning that was not possible before. This research has resulted in several publications including some at top-tier conferences in various disciplines. Our logs show that in the past two years, this cluster has been used for more than 313,000 GPU hours collectively by all researchers across the campus. Assuming $2 per GPU-hour on Amazon AWS, the campus has saved more than $625,000 by using this resource, which is a great return on investment. Obviously, this savings will continue to increase. We thank NSF for the support!

 

Moreover, this cluster has enabled graduate students to try their ideas that need large computational resources and publish papers. This will improve the research outcome and will lead to better training and opportunities for the students. Indeed, considering the broad usage of machine learning and particularly deep learning, in applications such as automotive, finance, and military, the students will be competitive in the job market.
